The state of California, USA has set high goals_x000D_ to shift its energy system towards a more sustainable one based on renewable_x000D_ energy (RE) resources. In 2015, it harvested more solar electricity than all_x000D_ other 49 U.S.A. states combined. Before 2009, no solar projects were permitted_x000D_ on public land in California. By 2015, there were already 29 solar project_x000D_ permissions in the South-West of the U.S.A.. Developing large-scale solar_x000D_ projects in the state of California has become increasingly challenging as new_x000D_ federal regulations seek to decrease the environmental footprint and impact of_x000D_ especially large-scale projects. On the other hand, the Obama administration_x000D_ gave the development of renewable energy sources priority by pledging to_x000D_ generate 20 gigawatt of power by 2020, which equals powering six million homes._x000D_ [1]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

The project

_x000D_ _x000D_

The Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System_x000D_ (ISEGS) is located in California’s Mojave Desert and was at the time of_x000D_ construction (2012) the largest concentrating solar power (CSP) plant in the_x000D_ USA. The power plant is based just below California’s Clark Mountain, close to_x000D_ the state line of Primm, Nevada. [2] The ISEGS plant occupies approximately 3,500 acres (ca. 1,416 ha) of_x000D_ federal land administered by the US Bureau of Land Management (BML). Upon_x000D_ completion, the project aimed to double the total solar electricity output_x000D_ generated in the USA. In 2012, the Ivanpah SEGS project was therefore awarded_x000D_ the ‘CSP Project of the year’ by the organization Solar Power Generation USA._x000D_ [3] The project is meant to be an “environmentally responsible project” [3], as it aims to contribute to the_x000D_ reduction of CO2 emission of around 400,000 tons on an annual basis. The_x000D_ technological system of CSP employed by BSE is considered to be one of the most_x000D_ land-efficient RE technologies. The heliostat layout is flexible and can thus_x000D_ be built around natural contours avoiding sensible vegetation and areas. [3] Due to water scarcity the Ivanpah_x000D_ SEGS uses a closed-loop air-cooling system allowing the plant to use 90%_x000D_ less water than equivalent power plants utilizing wet-cooling. [3] The director and vice president of_x000D_ the developing company BrightSource Energy stated the Ivanpah Solar_x000D_ power plant will be an important step to get California closer to its goal of_x000D_ generating 33% of its electricity by renewable energy (RE) resources by 2020. [2]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

Timeline

_x000D_ _x000D_

In 2006, the developer BrightSource Energy_x000D_ (BSE) applied for a pre-qualification with the Department of Energy (DOE)_x000D_ Loan Guarantee program. [2] After that, BSE submitted the first application for_x000D_ certification (AFC) to build a solar power plant in 2007. However, since then,_x000D_ environmental groups in California objected the project due to the possibility_x000D_ of disturbances of the tortoise habitat in the Ivanpah valley (see below). Nevertheless,_x000D_ the construction of the Ivanpah SEGS had its break ground date in_x000D_ October 2010 and was expected to deliver electricity to the two utility_x000D_ companies PG&E and Southern California Edison by 2013. [3] This goal was missed and electricity generation started in 2014. [2]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

Environmental_x000D_ impacts and related conflicts

_x000D_ _x000D_

There are two main ecological dangers expressed_x000D_ by environmental groups that are directly related to the Ivanpah solar projects._x000D_ The first environmental impact is on wildlife – more specifically on birds,_x000D_ insects and the desert tortoise, whereas the second is on water usage. Further,_x000D_ there is a controversy on the unions involved in the project.

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

1.    _x000D_ Impact_x000D_ on Birds and flying insects.

_x000D_ _x000D_

According to an article published on the_x000D_ platform Renewable Energy World there are some measurable and_x000D_ quantifiable impacts from the solar power plant on insects and birds. Birds physically_x000D_ strike all kinds of human-made infrastructure such as transmission lines,_x000D_ buildings or wind turbines. In general, most of these strikes have the nature of_x000D_ a physical collisions causing birds’ deaths, or (mortal) injuries. In the case_x000D_ of the ISEGS project, there are collisions between birds and the power tower’s_x000D_ heliostats, but also damages caused by “elevated concentrations of solar flux” [4], which are a ‘new’ form of human-made environmental impact. Solar flux_x000D_ is the reflected, concentrated sunlight close to the towers. Birds are_x000D_ suffering ‘feather singeing’ which impairs their flying ability and can thus_x000D_ lead to their death. [4] According to the conservation group ‘Center for Biological Diversity’,_x000D_ the ISEGS project could kill up to 28,380 birds annually. This number is an_x000D_ extrapolation from a study conducted by an environmental organization, which is_x000D_ opposing the project. [5] Among the affected species were hummingbirds, warblers, doves, swallows_x000D_ and sparrows. [4] Another study published in IEEE Spectrum mentions data gained by_x000D_ monitoring from October 2013 to October 2014 claims a range of 693 to 3,504_x000D_ birds from 83 different species and an additional 32 dead bats. [5]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

Some birds (nighthawks, yellow warblers [6]) of that region are feasting on insects (e.g. “caterpillars,_x000D_ grasshoppers, dragonflies, beetles, bees and wasps” [6]). These small insects are turned immediately into ash when entering a_x000D_ solar flux concentrated light beam.

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

In general, the closer the birds get to the_x000D_ solar towers, the higher their risk is of singeing respectively dying. In order_x000D_ to develop an effective deterrent, scientists of the Smithsonean Institution’s_x000D_ forensic lab analyzed which types of birds were affected. After the bird’s_x000D_ identification, a possible technological mitigation strategy is using the_x000D_ birds’ fear of predation.

_x000D_ _x000D_

In total there are three mitigation strategies_x000D_ consisting of three technologies. Firstly, ‘bio-acoustic deterrence’([4][5]), secondly, ‘nonlethal avian_x000D_ respiratory irritant’ and thirdly, equipping towers with ‘anti-perching spikes’_x000D_ [6].

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

2.     Desert tortoise

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

The environmental organization ‘Basin and_x000D_ Range Watch’  states on their webpage,_x000D_ that Ivanpah valley is of excellent quality as a desert tortoise habitat. In_x000D_ 1994, the so-called Desert Tortoise (Mojave Desert) Recovery Plan was_x000D_ established distinguishing between six “designated evolutionary significant units”_x000D_ of which the habiting Northeastern Mojave tortoises are the genetically most_x000D_ distinct ones. When the recovery plan was conducted the Ivanpah valley showed_x000D_ to have the highest known tortoise density with 200 to 250 animals per square_x000D_ kilometer. In 2011 the recovery plan was revised showing that large areas of_x000D_ the Ivanpah area do show “high potential” to support the desert tortoises. Scientists’_x000D_ findings demonstrated that conservation measures are required in order to_x000D_ ensure the survival viability of the population.  [7]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

In surveys, environmentalists have found 25_x000D_ desert tortoises around the project’s land as stated in an article found on a_x000D_ blog of the New York Times [8]. The environmental groups stated that BSE’s_x000D_ first reaction in reducing the total electricity producing capacity of the_x000D_ ISEGS power plant was a step into the right direction. Anyhow, it did not_x000D_ dissolve the environmentalist’s concerns, since BSE would not do anything to_x000D_ protect the desert tortoises by just reducing the project’s size and reducing_x000D_ energy generated. “This reconfiguration is pretty minimal from what we’ve seen,_x000D_ and it hasn’t really addressed the core issues on the impact on desert tortoise_x000D_ and rare plants” [8] said the Californian representative for Defenders of Wildlife,_x000D_ the environmental organization in charge. However, the company stated that significant_x000D_ changes were already made to the project, alluding a decrease of the overall_x000D_ output of the power plant from 440 to 392 MW. [8] The company BSE also hired an environmental consultant to review the_x000D_ new design. [8]

_x000D_ _x000D_

Later, fences around the plant’s territory were_x000D_ installed in order to protect the desert tortoises. The fences causes_x000D_ roadrunners (type of non-flying bird) to get trapped in the fences’ mesh and_x000D_ becoming easy prey for coyotes. In an further step Ivanpah’s environmental_x000D_ manager installed ‘road runner exits’ into the fence (holes about 8 inches in_x000D_ diameter and 18 inches above ground .[6]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

3.    _x000D_ Rare plant species

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

According to the environmental organization ‘Basin_x000D_ and Range Watch’ the Ivanpah valley in which the ISEGS is to be located. The_x000D_ valley within the Mojave Desert is valued by scientists to be of “unparalleled pristine_x000D_ quality among deserts” and also to be one of the “world’s last functional ecosystems”._x000D_ [7] In total twelve rare plant species_x000D_ were documented on the ISEGS’s project site such as the “Mojave Milkweed,_x000D_ White-margined Penstom, and Desert Pincushion” [7]. The California Energy Commission_x000D_ considered five of these plant species to be significant for the California_x000D_ Environmental Quality Act and concluded that a substantial portion of the their_x000D_ habitat would be threatened. The California Native Plant Society that a_x000D_ simple translocation of the plants would not be sufficient and that there is no_x000D_ known mitigation method compensating for the loss of rare plant habitat. Consequently,_x000D_ the only suitable mitigation strategy is not constructing in sensible plant’s_x000D_ habitat. [7]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

4.    _x000D_ Water controversy

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

The increasing need for scarce fresh water sources_x000D_ is a key issue and concern for the development of California’s renewable energy_x000D_ sector [11]. The Ivanpah project would use an estimated 25 million gallons of_x000D_ water per year mainly in order to wash its mirrors. Utilizing a wet-cooled_x000D_ solar through system would imply drawing 705 million gallons of water in the_x000D_ Mojave desert – an area of very scant rainfall. There is a general legal fight_x000D_ taking place in California where via a legal bill was being prepared that should_x000D_ allow the usage of  drinking water when_x000D_ harvesting RE power in California. Terry O’Brien, the California Energy_x000D_ Commission deputy director commented on this with the following: “By allowing_x000D_ projects to use fresh water, the bill would remove any incentives_x000D_ that developers have to use technologies that minimize water use,”. [9] Ivanpah’s developer consequently intends to swap to the solar tower_x000D_ technology in order to rid the problem of water scarcity in the Mojave desert._x000D_ Solar towers can be cooled with an air-cooling system needing to a great extent_x000D_ less water. In general, the downside from a business-perspective of using_x000D_ dry-cooling systems is that costs are added and the overall efficiency is_x000D_ reduced, which leads to less profit. However, BSE claims that deploying_x000D_ dry-cooling system in the Ivanpah project does not lead to a “prohibitive_x000D_ decline in power output”.  [9]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

5.     Tribal resistance

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

Phillip Smith is a Chemehuevi, an elder of the_x000D_ Colorado River Indian Tribe and Ron Van Fleet (Fort Mohave Indian Tribe) state_x000D_ about the cultural relevance of the plant’s site to their tribes. They tell_x000D_ that their ancestors have come to the “altars” (stones on the site of the_x000D_ Ivanpah plant) to “worship the divine and admire the Mojave Desert.” [10] In September 2010, about 20 protesters came to the sacred site to_x000D_ protect the 5.6-square-mile stretch. P. Smith stated that animals such as_x000D_ “desert tortoises, bighorn sheep, mountain lions, haws, snakes, and many_x000D_ sensitive medical plants” are “getting squeezed out” of the area and further_x000D_ that they – the local tribes are “their protectors”. [10] He further told that the company BrightSource Energy would_x000D_ destroy their home to profit from the cheap electricity of the sun stating that_x000D_ the project is about “fast money. It’s all fast money.” And that this goes_x000D_ against the living space of the indigenous tribes and the animals that have_x000D_ been living in the same area of the project’s site. P. Smith reminds that there_x000D_ were times with to cities such as Los Angeles and Las Vegas and that these_x000D_ ancient sites have been being of importance to the tribal cultures. [10]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

The reply of a BSE’s spokesman was that_x000D_ they had not heard of the American Indians’ concerns until then, adding that_x000D_ they (BSE) “share their passion for the desert” [10] and that they are confident that the approach they are taking “is the_x000D_ right approach from an environmental perspective”.[10]

other_types: National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act provides no recognition of indigenous people’s right to consultation or to access their traditional lands and resources. The authority to manage resource use ultimately lies in the hands of the national park warden, who grants the right of conditional use to local communities at his discretion. No mechanisms for co-management of park governance. Sherpa leaders are involved in promoting ICCA management. The Sherpa community and identity remains strong within the Khumbu region. Many traditional land use and resource management practices continue to this day and have at times even been encouraged by the government and park authorities. Areas of contention still exist, such as the recognition of Sherpa indigenous rights, and the ecological strain placed on the environment by unrestricted tourist growth.

In January 2020, TotalEnergies and Apache announced a significant oil discovery in Block 58 offshore Suriname. The find was commensurate with discoveries in the nearby Stabroek block offshore Guyana and sparked hopes for an oil bonanza in the country [1]. The oil companies continued exploring for oil with new wells and have since announced 5 successful drills, the latest in February 2022 [2]. Two further exploratory wells have failed to find commercial reserves in the block [3]. For now there is no clear development plan for the reserves, and the Final Investment Decision has been pushed forward to 2023 [4].


The Suriname economy has been historically linked to extractive sectors. Between the 17th and 19th century, the country's economy was initially focused on cocoa, sugar and cotton slave plantations under dutch colonial rule. In the 20th century, bauxite and aluminium became dominant sectors of the economy [5]. Currently, gold mining represents 75% of exports, with an important presence of artisanal small scale mining. Finally, the oil sector is becoming more important and now represents 10% of exports. Both the gold and oil sector are controlled through the national oil company Staatsolie which mostly developed onshore oil exploitations in Saramacca district until 2016. That year, after significant discoveries in the same oil basin in nearby Guyana, offshore exploration licences were put on tender to international oil companies, subject to participation rights for Staatsolie [6].


Local environmental activist Erlan Sleur, chairman of Probios, opposes the extraction of offshore oil and advocates to keep the oil in the ground. The arguments defend that an oil spill would spell a death sentence to the mangroves along the country’s coast. According to the organisation, the mangroves are the best defence against sea level rise, as they will grow higher with the ocean waters protecting the shoreline. Furthermore, they oppose seismic exploration test as they will disturb the ocean wildlife [7].


Erlan Sleur regrets there is not much opposition locally. People are convinced by the promises that the oil sector will bring rapid economic development and lift them out of poverty. However, he thinks that corruption and mismanagement will land the profits with the multinationals and the national cliques, and leave nothing for the Surinamese [7]. In a study on the oil deals and their financing by international development banks, the german environmental justice organisation urgewald, indeed finds that “ultra low royalty (6.5%) and tax rates for oil investments remain, while tax rates for non-oil sectors and citizens increase, with the heaviest burden falling on the poorest people”. They criticise the involvement of the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank in supporting the establishment of international oil companies in Suriname at the expense of expanding the country’s crippling debt and the devastation of the climate [8].


In compensation for leaving the oil in the ground, the local conservation organisation Probios demands rich countries pay Suriname for protecting nature [7]. In what initially would seem like a move towards the environmental justice demands from local organisations, TotalEnergies struck a deal with Suriname’s government in November 2021 to preserve the country’s forest. Under the agreement, the company would pay $50m in exchange for an unspecified amount of carbon credits. But this is not what local organisations demand, TotalEnergies wants to drill for oil and pay the crumps for forest protection without clear evidence demonstrating any emissions avoidance. BankTrack defends that such carbon credits schemes “reduce the incredible diversity of the planet’s forests, grasslands and wetlands to a commodity that will be traded, and in the process triggering a massive new resource grab from Indigenous Peoples, peasants and local communities, mainly in the global South.” BankTrack denounces the deal as “the greenwashing of oil Block 58” and reminds that no new fossil fuel projects are compatible with limiting global warming to 1.5ºC. The international organisation demands that banks and insurers stop supporting the expansion of the fossil fuel industry in general, and TotalEnergies’ Block 58 in particular [9].


The tragic global environmental injustice is patent in this deal with the devil: “as rich countries fail to deliver on their obligations to reduce emissions and provide climate and mitigation finance, a country that will be impacted severely by the consequences of climate change now finds itself in bed with an oil giant.” [9]

En Francais ci-dessous --- The issues concerning Mbeubeuss landfill are multiple and complex to solve. Located 27km away from the capital, Mbeubeuss is a means of subsistence for one of the poorest populations in Dakar suburbs while the open-air landfill causes high air and soil contamination in the Malika District where more than 17,000 people live. The waste picker community is largely formed by young people unable to find a job. Mbeubeuss landfill represents their last chance to make a living. About 4,000 informal waste pickers vigorously defend their source of revenue even though it highly puts their health and lives at risk. They are a marginalized and discriminated group among the Senegalese society but they have organized in the Bokk Diom Association in the late 1990s when the government tried to remove them and later were granted formal recognition. Bokk Diom continues fighting against their discrimination, and for their recognition, cohesion, and social rights.

There has been an ongoing discussion about the closure of Mbeubeuss landfill for many years. At stake is the generation of private profits from the management of waste. Foreign investment interests, mainly coordinated under the World Bank programs, have been proposing and influencing the Senegalese government. Already in 2005, a report from the Energy Sector Management Assistance Program (part of the World Bank) proposed the privatization of Mbeubeuss’ waste for the creation of a gas capture technology to generate electricity. The funds would have been provided through the UNFCCC’s Clean Development Mechanism but the project never materialized. By 2009, the closure of the Mbeubeuss landfill became conditionality for the relocation of the 3,000 households near Pikine, being displaced for the construction of a highway between Dakar and Diamniadio. The chosen relocation area was just two kilometers away from Mbeubeuss. The Senegalese government’s creditors (mainly the International Development Association, part of the World Bank Group) for the highway project were pressuring for the landfill closure. The World Bank was proposing to open a new site that would have only generated 300 jobs and where salaries would have been lower than the current earned revenues at Mbeubess.

The waste pickers defended their self-employment and mobilized through Bokk Diom and with the help of ENDA to oppose the project. As a result, the situation of the landfill remains still the same, open and managed by the informal waste pickers. Besides the World Bank and its associated programs, also other development agencies, such as the Canadian agency IDRC advocated for the closure of Mbeubeuss for sanitarian and environmental reasons. The agency funded the project “Pure” from 2006 to 2011 during which it monitored the social, health, and environmental impacts of the landfill on the living communities, the farmers and vegetable growers from Malika but also Diamalaye and Njagoo neighborhoods. These impacts should not be undermined, but the waste pickers fight for bottom-up mitigation solutions for the landfill impacts which takes into consideration their perspectives and needs, instead of a managerial, imposed perspective whose aim would be to foster private and foreign profits. They fiercely defend their source of livelihood. The involvement of international and foreign institutions is not necessarily going against the waste pickers’ will. For instance, Bokk Diom has set up a school for the children of the dump with financial help from European organizations (French Agence Francaise du Developpement, the Luxembourg Agency for Development and the Belgian Ministry for Cooperation). The waste pickers also obtained funds from the United Nations Development Program to construct a medical center and the International Labor Organization has trained youth from the dump in other professions such as carpenter or baker. Security issues remain recurrent in the landfill and put at risk the lives of more than 400 waste pickers living inside the site.

The most recent tragedies happened in December 2016 when a massive fire - the so-far largest ever recorded at the landfill - killed three people. This also caused economic damage to the community as many waste pickers lost tons of recycled waste. Another fire happened in March 2017. After these tragedies, the public authorities committed to proposing a new study on the possibilities of the future of the landfill, expected by June 2017. In February 2018, another massive fire broke out at the Mbeubeuss landfill, destroying stored recycled waste, shelters, and most notably, the facilities of a small recycling business run by one of the founders of Bokk Diom, who started as a waste picker in the 1970s and now employed 75 people. This induced the association to stronger mobilize for on-site improvements at Mbeubeuss and also a crowdfunding campaign was started.

As of 2019/20, Mbeubeuss landfill is frequented by 4,000 waste pickers that are members of Bokk Diom and pay an annual union fee and even more who are not, and extends over an area of 175 hectares. The situation at the landfill was recently described by media as “out of control” and “an ecological and sanitary bomb”. While the waste picker community continues to face dangerous working conditions, insecurity, and a lack of social and health protection, also locals suffer from the adverse impacts of uncontrolled dumping. In December 2019, a group of nearby residents called ‘Mbeubeuss Dafa Doy’ (from the Malika, Yeumbeul Nord et Sud, Keur Massar, and Tivaouane Peul communities) staged protests and criticized the misinformation by and inaction of public authorities, as the dump closure was already promised in 2012. The group demanded the relocation of the site and announced that, if necessary, they will proceed with the protests and block garbage trucks from entering the site.

In 2019, the organization WIEGO (Women in Informal Employment – Globalizing and Organizng) together with the the ILO launched a project to improve conditions for the waste pickers of Mbeubeuss and strengthen their organizing in a cooperative. The cooperation was started with a two-day workshop that brought together informal waste pickers, leaders of Bokk Diom, and several institutions involved in waste management. WIEGO, as part of its Focal Cities initiative, has been working with informal workers across the city and among others initiated a project to improve the position of informal women waste pickers, including elderly, who are unlikely to find formal employment. They provided training in cooperative management and the strengthening of women’s worker identity. It supported the women’s cooperative ‘AVER-B’ that brings together street vendors, domestic workers, waste pickers, and informal food manufacturers in marketing their products. Bokk Diom, which to 60 percent of women, now also has a Women’s Recycling Committee that aims to strengthen women’s rights at Mbeubeuss landfill.

Most recently, new plans to modernize, rehabilitate and enclose the Mbeubeuss landfill were pushed forward by international institutions. In 2020, the Senegalese government received a new $US 125 loan from the International Development Association (IDA), a World Bank subsidiary, to modernize waste management in several cities. According to the plans, a public-private partnership should be established in Mbeubeuss to establish a waste treatment and disposal system in several phases. This would, first, include emergency measures to ensure safety at the site and prevent the entering of unauthorized persons. Later on, the site should become remodeled and optimized, including the installing of a leachate treatment system and a recycling center, in which former waste pickers would become employed.

The year 2020 brought the so far most visible mobilization of waste pickers in Dakar, as waste pickers of the Bokk Diom association held a silent demonstration march on the Global Waste Pickers Day, 1st of march, to commemorate the struggle of informal waste pickers around the globe. They also held a press conference in which they presented a memorandum with a counter-proposal to the new Mbeubeuss landfill modernization project. This, most notably, concerns a higher number of waste pickers to become part of the new landfill project and the creation of further opportunities to include waste pickers in municipal waste management.


***

En Francais --- Les problèmes concernant la décharge de Mbeubeuss sont multiples et complexes à résoudre. Mbeubeuss est un moyen de subsistance pour les recycleurs informels, une des populations les plus pauvres de la banlieue de Dakar, alors que qu’en même temps la décharge en plein air provoque une forte contamination de l'air et du sol dans le district de Malika où vivent plus de 17 000 personnes. La communauté des recycleurs est constituée par des jeunes incapables de trouver un emploi à Dakar. Mbeubeuss se trouve à seulement 27 km de la capitale. La décharge représente leur dernière chance de gagner de quoi vivre. Les 4.000 recycleurs informels défendent vigoureusement leur source de revenus, même si celle-ci met leur santé et leur vie en danger. La communauté de recycleurs est marginalisée et discriminée dans la société sénégalaise. Elle s’est organisée avec la création du Bokk Diom à la fin des années 1990, lorsque le gouvernement a tenté de les évincer du site. Ils ont alors été formellement reconnus par le gouvernement. Bokk Diom continue de lutter contre leur discrimination, pour leur reconnaissance, leur cohésion et leurs droits sociaux. La discussion de la fermeture de Mbeubeuss se poursuit depuis plusieurs années. Les investissements étrangers, principalement coordonnés par des programmes dépendant de la Banque Mondiale, proposent et influencent le gouvernement sénégalais. Ce qui intéresse ces investissements ce sont les profits qui seraient générés par une gestion privée des déchets. Déjà en 2005, un rapport du Programme d'Aide à la Gestion du Secteur de l'Energie (membre de la Banque mondiale) a proposé la privatisation des déchets de Mbeubeuss pour la capture de gaz afin de produire de l'électricité. Les financements auraient été fournis par le Mécanisme de Développement Propre de la CCNUCC. Mais le projet ne s'est jamais concrétisé. En 2009, la fermeture de la décharge de Mbeubeuss était une condition pour la relocalisation des 3 000 ménages près de Pikine, déplacés pour la construction d'une autoroute entre Dakar et Diamniadio. En effet, la zone choisie pour la réinstallation de ces familles était à 2 kilomètres de la décharge. Les créanciers du gouvernement sénégalais (principalement l'Association Internationale de Développement, groupe membre de la Banque Mondiale) pour le projet routier pressaient la fermeture du site Mbeubeuss. En contrepartie, la Banque Mondiale proposait d'ouvrir un nouveau site qui n'aurait généré que 300 emplois et dont les salaires auraient été inférieurs aux revenus actuellement gagnés par les recycleurs. Bokk Diom s’est mobilisé, avec l'aide d'ENDA pour s'opposer au projet. Les recycleurs ont vigoureusement défendu leur travail indépendant. En conséquence, la situation de la décharge demeure la même, gérée par les récupérateurs de déchets informels. Outre la Banque Mondiale et ses programmes associés, d'autres agences de développement, comme l'agence canadienne CRDI / CRDI, plaident en faveur de la fermeture de Mbeubeuss pour des raisons sanitaires et environnementales. L'agence a financé le projet «Pure» de 2006 à 2011, au cours duquel elle a surveillé les impacts sociaux, sanitaires et environnementaux de la décharge sur les communautés avoisinantes, sur les élevages de porc et la production de légumes à Malika et dans les quartiers de Diamalaye et Njagoo. Ces impacts ne devraient pas être ignorés, mais les recycleurs se battent pour défender des solutions d'atténuation de ces impacts qui tiennent compte de leurs points de vue et de leurs besoins, contre une perspective imposée par le haut dont l'objectif serait avant tout de favoriser le profit d’acteurs privés et étrangers. L’implication des Institutions Internationales et étrangères ne va pas nécessairement contre la volonté des recycleurs, au contraire certains acteurs collaborent avec la communauté de Mbeubeuss. Par exemple, Bokk Diom a mis en place une école pour les enfants de la décharge grâce à l'aide financière des organisations européennes (Agence française de développement, Agence luxembourgeoise pour le développement et Ministère belge de la coopération). Les récupérateurs de déchets ont également obtenu des fonds de la part du Programme des Nations Unies pour le Développement afin de construire un centre médical et l'Organisation Internationale du Travail a formé les jeunes de la décharge à d'autres professions comme la boulangerie ou la menuiserie. Les problèmes de sécurité restent récurrents dans la décharge. Deux récentes tragédies ont eu lieu en décembre 2016 lorsqu'un incendie dans la décharge a tué trois personnes et en mars 2017 un autre incendie s'est produit. A la suite de ces tragédies, les autorités se sont engagées à proposer une nouvelle étude concernant l’avenir de Mbeubeuss. L’étude est  attendue pour juin 2017.

La Raffineria di Roma nasce per opera dei conti Miani nei primi anni _x000D_ ‘50 nei pressi di Trastevere. Nel 1965 viene rilevata dalla Total Fina _x000D_ Italia S.p.A. e spostata nell'attuale sede di Ponte Galeria, a ovest di _x000D_ Roma, tra l’Aurelia, il Grande Raccordo Anulare e la Roma Civitavecchia _x000D_ [1].

Quest’area, Malagrotta, è soggetta ad una forte pressione _x000D_ ambientale, infatti, nel raggio di 50 km² sono presenti anche la nota _x000D_ discarica di rifiuti urbani, un inceneritore di rifiuti ospedalieri e _x000D_ farmaci scaduti dotato di un sistema per il recupero energetico _x000D_ (termovalizzatore), depositi di idrocarburi e cave per inerti [2]. La _x000D_ raffineria è stata per molti anni l’unico polo di lavorazione e _x000D_ distribuzione di prodotti petroliferi dell’Italia centrale.

Fino _x000D_ al 2010 la quota di maggioranza della raffineria era di proprietà della _x000D_ Total Fina [3]. A seguito della joint venture tra Total e Erg, la _x000D_ nascente TotalErg diviene proprietaria al cento per cento dell'impianto _x000D_ [4]. Alla fine del 2012, viste le difficoltà del settore, la TotalErg _x000D_ decide di cessare l'attività di raffinazione mantenendo in funzione _x000D_ solamente il polo logistico per lo stoccaggio e la distribuzione di _x000D_ carburanti già lavorati [5].

Decisione presa anche a causa della _x000D_ forte concorrenza che le società asiatiche e mediorientali esercitano _x000D_ nel settore petrolifero. Infatti, grazie al minor costo dell'energia, a _x000D_ una legislazione più permissiva per quanto riguarda le normative _x000D_ ambientali, ai vantaggi fiscali di cui spesso queste società possono _x000D_ godere e anche a un costo del lavoro nettamente più basso, il mercato _x000D_ viene inondato dal petrolio di queste zone, facendo diventare _x000D_ sconveniente la produzione di idrocarburi in Italia, come nel resto _x000D_ d'Europa [6].

A partire da questa situazione e visto l'andamento _x000D_ altalenante dei mercati, l'Unione Petrolifera stimava, nella primavera _x000D_ del 2012, che in Italia fossero a rischio oltre 7500 posti di lavoro, _x000D_ considerando che ogni raffineria, indotto compreso, occupava in media _x000D_ 1500 persone [7].

Quanto questa stima fosse realistica, lo ha _x000D_ dimostrato il fatto che, oltre alla struttura romana, negli ultimi anni _x000D_ sono stati chiusi anche gli impianti di Falconara, di proprietà _x000D_ dell'Api, e quello di Gela, di proprietà dell'ENI [5].

Nel caso _x000D_ specifico della Raffineria di Roma, a partire dal giugno del 2012 si _x000D_ sono susseguite varie iniziative e manifestazioni di protesta da parte _x000D_ dei lavoratori nei confronti dell'azienda per evitare licenziamenti di _x000D_ massa. La TotalErg S.p.A., però, non aveva presentato tempestivamente un_x000D_ vero e proprio piano occupazionale, pur avendo annunciato la _x000D_ trasformazione della raffineria in un polo logistico per lo stoccaggio, e_x000D_ quindi alla fine dello stesso anno centinaia di persone si ritrovarono _x000D_ senza lavoro [7][8].

Nel contempo, all'interno del dibattito _x000D_ pubblico, si è ricominciato a parlare anche della pericolosità del sito _x000D_ contro il quale, per lungo tempo, gli ambientalisti e i movimenti civici_x000D_ avevano dato battaglia. Per anni, infatti, le ciminiere, a due passi _x000D_ dalla discarica di Roma, sono state il simbolo dell'aspetto più _x000D_ distruttivo di un modello di sviluppo altamente impattante sia per _x000D_ l’ambiente che per la salute [7].

È per questo motivo che a _x000D_ partire dagli anni ’90 furono incoraggiati diversi studi epidemiologici –_x000D_ che tuttora continuano ad essere effettuati con cadenza periodica – _x000D_ vista la presenza nella stessa area di diversi impianti industriali e il_x000D_ conseguente aumento della preoccupazione dei residenti riguardo i _x000D_ possibili rischi per la loro salute. I risultati delle indagini (i più _x000D_ recenti sono datati aprile 2013) hanno dimostrato che ci sono stati _x000D_ eccessi di mortalità per varie tipologie tumorali – tra le quali _x000D_ spiccano quelle ai polmoni e alla vescica oltre che decessi causati da _x000D_ tumori celebrali e mieloma multiplo – tra i lavoratori della raffineria _x000D_ che si sono succeduti negli anni [2]. Dagli stessi studi epidemiologici _x000D_ non è, invece, emersa una diretta correlazione tra l'aumento di malattie_x000D_ tumorali tra la popolazione che vive nelle vicinanze della raffineria e_x000D_ la raffineria stessa [2].

In tempi più recenti, la Raffineria di _x000D_ Roma è tornata alla ribalta delle cronache per dei furti di gasolio _x000D_ avvenuti nel febbraio del 2015, in cui sono stati forati i tubi della _x000D_ condotta dell'impianto, procurando un'enorme perdita di carburante _x000D_ (oltre 5mila litri) nel canale delle Vignole e nel terreno adiacente _x000D_ alla zona della raffineria, compromettendo irreparabilmente l'ecosistema_x000D_ ambientale dell'intera area [9].

A seguito di questo avvenimento,_x000D_ la Prefettura di Roma, con Decreto prot. n. 185764 del 2 luglio 2015, _x000D_ ha approvato il Piano di Emergenza Esterna (PEE) per la Raffineria di _x000D_ Roma visti i rilevanti rischi di incidente [10].

Nonostante il _x000D_ conflitto, almeno dal punto di vista della produzione, sembrava essere _x000D_ chiuso, nell'Agosto del 2017 una novità ha riacceso l'allarme sulla _x000D_ raffineria. Il primo Agosto 2017 infatti è stata avvitata la procedura _x000D_ di verifica di assoggetabilità ambientale presentata dalla raffineria di_x000D_ Roma S.p.A. per le modifiche impiantistiche presso il deposito di _x000D_ Pantano di Grano per l’implementazione di un sistema di ricezione, _x000D_ stoccaggio ed esportazione del greggio estratto dai giacimenti Tempa _x000D_ Rossa. Nello specifico "il progetto prevede la possibilità di garantire _x000D_ il transito settimanale di circa 22.950 m3

di grezzo provenienti _x000D_ dal centro trattamento olii di Corleto di Perticara in Basilicata. other_types:
There are three operating uranium mines in Australia -Ranger in Kakadu National Park in Northern Territory; Olympic Dam in South Australia; and Beverley with Four Mile in South Australia.  Ranger is situated within the perimeter of the World Heritage listed Kakadu National Park (Kakadu).  Kakadu has two other rich uranium deposits yet to be developed - Jabiluka and Koongarra.

Ranger was developed against the wishes of local traditional owners - the Mirrar people.  Senior Traditional Owner Toby Gangale, opposed plans for uranium exploration and mining on his country in the 1970s.  His opposition, along with that of other local Aboriginal people, was overruled by the Federal Government when it legislated for the development of the Ranger Uranium Mine in 1976.  Ranger commenced operations in 1980, the mine is now run by Energy Resources Australia (ERA) which is majority owned by Rio Tinto. 

Since the early 1980s, yellowcake from Mirarr land has been sent to fuel nuclear reactors in Japan, Europe and elsewhere. By 2019 Ranger uranium mine is now coming to the end of its life. Mining has concluded and minimal processing of stockpiled ore continues as the company contemplates the enormous rehabilitation task.

ERA announced the closure and rehabilitation of the entire site by 2021.  In December 2014 ERA called for public comment on its environmental impact statement for a massive new ‘Ranger 3 Deeps’ underground mine. The Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF, Sweeney 2014) responded that the proposed mining technique was untested in monsoonal tropical areas and risked the rehabilitation of the site.  ACF cited the 200+ leaks, spills, accidents and license breaches at Ranger Uranium Mine to date and the negative impacts on local (Indigenous) communities living downstream as well as the environmentally and culturally significance of the environment: ‘It is home to the world's richest breeding grounds for migratory tropical water birds, majestic waterfalls, vast wetlands teeming with wildlife, Indigenous rock art sites and over 50,000 years of living tradition and cultural practice’.

After the Fukushima accident, the traditional landowners were worried also by the impact of the activity on their land has on others. The possibility of uranium from Mirarr land being incorporated into a nuclear weapon or present at the site of a nuclear accident is therefore of enormous concern to Mirarr. Despite assurances from successive Federal Governments that Australian uranium is only sold for nuclear power, the fact remains that is impossible to guarantee Australian uranium does not end up in nuclear weapons. In April 2011, following the earthquake, tsunami and subsequent nuclear disaster in Japan, Yvonne Margarula wrote to UN Secretary-General Ban ki-Moon and expressed her sorrow at the impacts radiation is having on the lives of Japanese people. She noted that, ‘it is likely that the radiation problems at Fukushima are, at least in part, fuelled by uranium derived from our traditional lands. This makes us feel very sad.’  (1).

Leaving aside the damage that the extracted uranium has done elsewhere, the local rehabilitation costs amount to hundreds of millions of dollars.  After the price collapse following the Fukushima nuclear crisis, times in the uranium trade were difficult. Coupled with a mandated end to commercial operations by early 2021, Rio Tinto has accepted the era of mining has now been replaced by the need for rehabilitation.

But the challenge for Energy Resources of Australia and Rio Tinto, who own and operate the mine, is not simple. It is to ensure radioactive and contaminated mine tailings are "physically isolated from the environment for at least 10,000 years [and that] any contaminants arising from the tailings will not result in any detrimental environmental impacts for at least 10,000 years."(2).

other_types:
El 13 de junio de 2023, la comunidad de Escolásticas, Pedro Escobedo en Querétaro, vivió una confrontación entre pobladores y tres agencias policiales (dos municipales y una estatal) que derivó en once personas detenidas [1]. Esto ocurrió mientras pobladores, con presencia importante de mujeres y niños, se manifestaban por la aprehensión contra tres personas por el presunto delito despojo de un predio en la localidad de El Sabino [2].

La Fiscalía argumentó una detención legal mientras los pobladores señalaron el uso indebido del aparato penal para favorecer a un particular [3]. El origen del conflicto es la definición de propiedad de un predio en cuyo interior se encuentran manantiales de competencia federal y árboles sabinos milenarios, un área de importante valor ecológico [4]. Las hectáreas se encuentran en disputa legal [5] entre la propiedad comunal datada de 1936 y una serie de compra ventas privadas señaladas como irregulares por no contar con la autorización de la asamblea ejidal. La disputa tiene precedentes de conflictos, incluyendo amenazas y agresiones por parte de distintos particulares hacia la comunidad ejidal en 1936, 1968, 1973 y 1996. Quien se ostenta como el más reciente propietario es quien interpuso la denuncia penal motivo de las detenciones. Investigaciones periodísticas revelaron que mantiene una estrecha relación de favorecimiento indebido con el gobierno local [6].

Grupos ambientalistas como Vocer@s de la Madre Tierra han acompañado a la comunidad de Escolásticas en la protección y defensa de su tierra común. En abril de 2023 realizaron señalamientos sobre la construcción de un muro cercando el área de manantiales conocida como "Los Sabinos" y  la alteración de árboles endémicos, los cuales califican como susceptibles de protección federal por su valor como patrimonio natural y seguridad hídrica. También detectaron venta privada de pipas de agua proveniente de los manatiales comunitarios [7].

Durante el operativo, las 11 personas detenidas, entre ellas un menor de 17 años, sufrieron fuertes lesiones, permanecieron temporalmente desaparecidas y fueron localizadas en centros penitenciarios solo después de la intervención judicial. La Defensoría de los Derechos Humanos de Querétaro (DDHQ), ante quien se interpuso queja formal, no inició queja de oficio ni medidas cautelares pese a que su personal estuvo en el lugar de los hechos [8].

Luego de que redes nacionales, actores internacionales y organizaciones locales emitieron pronunciamientos, además de la presión social y recursos de amparo, el 20 de junio, 9 personas fueron liberadas bajo amenaza y aún en condición de penalmente acusadas [9].

Igual que en otros casos de defensa del territorio, en Escolásticas se reportó estigmatización de la protesta por parte de las autoridades [10] intimidación a las personas defensoras [11] y criminalización. Este es el tercer caso de represión a la defensa del agua en el estado de Querétaro en 2022 y 2023 [12].

other_types:
The case is about the environmental group Milieudefensie/Friends of the Earth suing the Royal Dutch Shell for failing to play its part in the fight against climate change and thereby breaching its duty of care under Dutch law and human rights obligations.

Established in 1971, Milieudefensie is the Netherland’s most influential climate organization. Since 1972, it has been a member of Friends of the Earth International, the largest grassroots environmental network on an international level [1]. Shell, previously known as Royal Dutch Shell [2], is an Anglo-Dutch multinational and one of the largest oil and gas companies worldwide and in consequence one of the biggest corporate producers of greenhouse gases [3].

In 2019, Mileudefensie together with other NGOs and the signatures of more than 17.000 citizens, started a lawsuit against Shell arguing that Shell has an obligation to contribute to the prevention of climate change on basis of the duty of care under the unwritten standard of the Dutch Civil Code, Book 6 Section 162 and the Paris Climate Agreement of 2015. In line with these legal foundations, they demanded that Shell reduce its emissions by 45% by 2030 - compared to the 2019 level - and use its great influence to provide consumers with more sustainable choices. According to Milieudefensie, Shell had known the dangerous effects of the company’s emissions for decades and failed to take appropriate action up to the present time [4].

Shell defended itself by giving mainly two arguments: First, they argued that cutting out further emissions would not have any effect because those emissions would be replaced by other companies due to the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS). Second, Shell argued that there was no legal basis for the company to be sued for its emissions and that the plaintiff’s arguments were too general in order to fall within the scope of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) [5].

On May 26 in 2021, The Hague District Court ruled that Shell had to reduce its emissions by 45% by 2030 across emissions from its own operations and effects of the company’s produced oil. According to the court, this decision was made on the basis of the duty of care under the unwritten standard of the Dutch Civil Code and the Paris climate goals [6].

As of today, Shell has not taken any action to further reduce its emissions in line with the court's decision. It should also be mentioned that the company moved their headquarters from the Netherlands to the UK, even though the company denies any relation of the relocation to the court’s judgment but explains it mainly with the 15% dividend tax that the Dutch government puts on big multinationals [7]. In April 2022, Milieudefensie sent a letter to the company's board of directors asking for urgent action. Shell, for its part, appealed against the court's decision in June 2022, and it remains to be seen what the outcome of this conflict will be [5]. However, it raises the broader question of whether private companies can be held responsible for taking appropriate action on climate change and liable for failing to do so.

_x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_

Shanxi Antai Group (山西安泰集团, Antai) is a publicly listed company (600408.SH) located at Yi’an_x000D_ Town of Jiexiu City in Jinzhong, Shanxi Province, China. Yi’an Town, home to a_x000D_ population of 59,043 as of 2017[1], is known for its coke production. Jiexiu City is also considered China’s_x000D_ largest metallurgical coke production and export base, with Antai as one of_x000D_ China’s six largest merchant coke suppliers.[1], [2] Antai’s subsidiary Shanxi Hong’an Coking Technology Co., Td. (山西宏安焦化科技有限公司) was founded in 2004 and specializes in the production and sales of_x000D_ coke and coking by-products. According to the disclosure by the International_x000D_ Finance Corporation (IFC) which provided a USD 70 million loan to the coking_x000D_ subsidiary of Antai in 2004, the company’s coking plant was expected to produce_x000D_ 1 million tons of coke per year when completed.[3], [4]

_x000D_ _x000D_

Antai is a key target under state_x000D_ monitoring and control in terms of environmental pollution (国控重点污染企业). According to All-China Environment Federation (ACEF, 中华环保联合会), the data published by Automatic Pollutant Monitoring Platform for_x000D_ Corporates under Intense State Monitoring and Control (国控重点污染源自动监控平台) by MEE_x000D_ indicated that the percentage of days that Antai’s coking plant’s air_x000D_ pollutants including sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides exceeded the standard_x000D_ was as high as 93% between June 2015 and October 2016 after China’s new environmental_x000D_ protection law came into effect.[5] Antai’s subsidiary Hong’an Coking Technology was also notified and publicized_x000D_ by the Environmental Protection Bureau of Shanxi Province for its excessive_x000D_ emissions for two consecutive quarters in August 2015.[6] In 2016, ACEF filed a public interest civil litigation on the_x000D_ ground of air pollution responsibility dispute at the Intermediate People's_x000D_ Court of Jinzhong City, Shanxi Province (山西晋中中级人民法院) and_x000D_ requested the court to order Antai’s coking plant to bear the cost of_x000D_ atmospheric environmental restoration cost of CNY 2,098,553.[5], [7]

_x000D_ _x000D_

The Intermediate_x000D_ People's Court of Jinzhong City, Shanxi Province accepted the case on January_x000D_ 19, 2017. Considering that Shanxi Antai Group had completed the desulfurization_x000D_ technology upgrade at that time and the pollutant emission level had met the_x000D_ standard, the company and ACEF voluntarily reached a mediation agreement with_x000D_ the support of the court in organizing the mediation in March 2018. As a_x000D_ result, Shanxi Antai Group agreed to pay for CNY 537,800 for atmospheric_x000D_ environment restoration costs, which will be used for the environmental resource_x000D_ restoration in Jinzhong City. Besides, the plaintiff’s attorney’s agency fees,_x000D_ travel expenses, and case acceptance fees incurred in this case are all borne_x000D_ by the company. Antai also made an apology publicly for_x000D_ the pollution incident, committed to a sustainable development strategy, and_x000D_ welcomed the general public to monitor its environmental governance efforts. [8], [9] This public_x000D_ interest litigation case, along with two other cases filed by ACEF on the issue_x000D_ of air pollution, was awarded among the “Top 10 Public Interest Litigation in_x000D_ China” in 2016.[10]

_x000D_ _x000D_

During the public interest litigation case investigation_x000D_ and even after the mediation, there were still complaints regarding the coking_x000D_ plant’s pollution by local residents on China’s social media Weibo and reported_x000D_ by journalists between 2017 and 2020. A journalist from Judicial Weekly (法治周刊) documented the pollution after conducting a site visit in Jiexiu_x000D_ in August 2017.[6] The site visit covered two different coking plants in Jiexiu, after_x000D_ which the journalist filed a complaint to the Environmental Protection Bureau_x000D_ of Jiexiu City and received no response. The journalist wrote an article in_x000D_ which he questioned the environmental governance and monitoring capacity of the_x000D_ local government of Jiexiu, especially considering that the central_x000D_ government’s environmental inspection had started in 2015.[6]

_x000D_ _x000D_

In March 2018, the local residents at_x000D_ Liujiazhai Village (刘家寨村) in Jiexiu near the coking plant of Antai’s subsidiary Hong’an_x000D_ Coking Technology filed a complaint to the Secretary of Shanxi Province Party_x000D_ Committee (山西省委书记) via the People.com (人民网) website.[11] The Shanxi Provincial Committee of Social Affairs and Public_x000D_ Opinion Office (山西省委社情民意办公室) provided a response to the residents’ complaint. The response_x000D_ indicated that the Jiexiu City Environmental Protection Bureau requested Shanxi_x000D_ Yuhang Environmental Monitoring Co., Ltd. (山西榆航环境监测有限公司) to_x000D_ monitor the environmental performance of the Hong’an coking plant, and the_x000D_ monitoring report showed that the plant’s emissions mostly met the standard. On_x000D_ the other hand, Jiexiu City’s municipality government issued the_x000D_ "Implementation Plan for the Relocation and Resettlement of Residents_x000D_ within the Sanitation Protection Area of ​​Jiexiu City" (《介休市卫生防护距离内居民搬迁安置实施方案》) and the "Responsibility Decomposition and Accountability Plan_x000D_ for the Relocation and Resettlement of Residents within the Sanitation_x000D_ Protection Area of ​​Jiexiu City" (《介休市卫生防护距离内居民搬迁安置责任分解及责任追究方案》). The local government of Yi'an Town became responsible for the relocation_x000D_ and resettlement and announced the following task plans: 1) On the basis of the_x000D_ preliminary investigation, combined with the actual situation and the will of_x000D_ the villagers, implement monetary compensation and transitional resettlement_x000D_ for residents of Liujiazhai Village that are severely polluted by Hong'an_x000D_ coking plant’s dust. 2) Establish the Liujiazhai Village Relocation and_x000D_ Resettlement Working Group and formulate a relocation plan with the guidance of_x000D_ the Yi'an Town government. The working group is expected to convene meetings_x000D_ for voting on relevant matters and make plans for the resettlement community or_x000D_ use existing affordable housing to carry out the resettlement for the whole Liujiazhai_x000D_ Village.[11]

_x000D_ _x000D_

In July 2018, there was another media_x000D_ report which disclosed that more than 10 migrant workers claimed that Hong’an Coking_x000D_ Technology had failed to pay the salary of the migrant.[12] The workers were hired by a company in Shandong Province to work on_x000D_ the coke oven tail gas desulfurization project at Hong’an Coking Technology_x000D_ between 2015-2016.[12]  The installation fee and the_x000D_ workers’ salaries added up to CNY 4.23 million, which was still not paid in_x000D_ full after 3 years. The journalist from the media that received the migrant_x000D_ workers’ complaint made futher investigation and also found environmental_x000D_ pollution related violations at the coking plant and called for further attention_x000D_ from the government authorities.[12]

_x000D_ _x000D_

In 2019, an anti-corruption legal case in_x000D_ Jinzhong City of Shanxi Province indicated that Antai Group paid bribery amounting_x000D_ to CNY 1.15 million to Qin Taiming, former vice chairman of Shanxi Jinzhong_x000D_ CPPCC, in return for environmental and operation permits between 2002 and 2013._x000D_ While the details were not known, it corresponds to earlier reports in_x000D_ 2003-2004 regarding illegal land dispossesion by Antai in early years of its_x000D_ operation in Yi’an Town.[13][14]

_x000D_ _x000D_

The question raised by the journalist in_x000D_ 2017 was further uncovered in a media report in July 2020 after Jiexiu received_x000D_ the ecological and environmental inspection by the provincial government_x000D_ representatives. According to the report, Jiexiu City issued the "Rectification_x000D_ and Implementation Plan in response to the feedback from the Ecology and_x000D_ Environment Bureau of Shanxi Province" (《贯彻落实山西省生态环境厅督察反馈意见整改方案》) on 19 January 2020 based on the feedback from the environmental_x000D_ inspection team of Shanxi Province after unannounced site visits to Jiexiu. The_x000D_ implementation plan proposed to strictly inspect and investigate the_x000D_ environmental issues and accountability of corresponding entities and rectify_x000D_ within a restricted time frame. In June 2020, feedback from the local residents_x000D_ indicated that the highly polluting companies e.g. coal washing, coking and_x000D_ quarrying continued their business as usual even during the rectification_x000D_ period. According to local residents and workers, the local government was_x000D_ obviously involved in covering up the polluting behaviors and colluding with_x000D_ the polluting companies in face of the environmental inspection by higher level_x000D_ government authorities.[15]

other_types:
_x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_ _x000D_

The state of Virginia has set itself the goal_x000D_ to achieve 3,000 megawatts (MW) of electricity generation by solar power. The_x000D_ Utah-based company called Sustainable Power Group (sPower)_x000D_ proposed the project Spotsylvania Solar Energy Center (SSEC) that_x000D_ has a planned rated capacity of 500 MW. [1],[2]

_x000D_ _x000D_

Step by step, solar energy production is_x000D_ settling at the East Coast of the U.S., where North Carolina is the largest_x000D_ provider of solar-based solar energy. The SSEC project shall be located east of_x000D_ the Rocky Mountains. Anyhow opinions on the project are conflictive ranging_x000D_ from viewing the project as a “dangerous eyesore” [3] to a local economy boost. [3] The solar panels would cover around_x000D_ 3,500 acres (1416,4 hectares) making it the largest solar power project at the_x000D_ east coast. [4] The project site would encompass_x000D_ 6,350 acres (2569,8 hectares), of which at least 2,000 acres (809,4 hectares) shall_x000D_ be left undeveloped and conserved. [2]

_x000D_ _x000D_

The location proposal is Spotsylvania County_x000D_ (SSC) where 130,000 persons are residing at, is mainly famous for its Civil War_x000D_ history and agriculture. [1] The developing company sPower_x000D_ proposed in total three solar fields in the rural part SSC of Virginia where_x000D_ the largest would be constructed on land designated for agricultural use. [1] SSC is approximately 60 miles south_x000D_ of Washington D.C. [3]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

Project involvement:

_x000D_ _x000D_

The Utah-based company Sustainable Power_x000D_ Group (sPower) proposed the SSEC project. [1] The 500MW-solar project is being_x000D_ developed, owned and operated by sPower, which itself is owned by a_x000D_ joint venture partnership between AES and AIMCo (Alberta Investment_x000D_ Management Cooperation) company [5] and was founded acquired in February,_x000D_ 2017 [2]. According to the SSEC project’s_x000D_ official website the construction could begin in March 2019 and last until_x000D_ December 2020. [2]

_x000D_ _x000D_

Microsoft contracted for 315 MW of the SSC_x000D_ project’s capacity, [6] for supplying two of its data_x000D_ centers that are located in Virginia that require “massive amounts of_x000D_ electricity” [4].

_x000D_ _x000D_

The company Microsoft is billing the 315_x000D_ MW power of electricity with a power purchase agreement (PPA) from the two_x000D_ solar fields Pleinmont 1 and 2 that comprise over 750,000 solar photovoltaic (PV)_x000D_ modules. The scope of the PPA would make it the largest to date. Microsoft already_x000D_ had another 20 MW project in Virginia two years ago (2016). The software giant is_x000D_ financially involved as it tries to source its energy consumption by renewable_x000D_ energy and carbon offsetting. [7] By 2020 Microsoft wants to achieve_x000D_ 60% electricity generation by RE and is therefore investing into electricity generation_x000D_ projects in the field of renewable energy. [5] In a press release from December,_x000D_ 2018 sPower mentions other corporate off-takers for the electricity,_x000D_ which are: “Microsoft, Apple, Akamai, Etsy and the University of Richmond.“ [8] See also [1].

_x000D_ _x000D_

The electrical substation close-by is run by Dominion_x000D_ Energy.  The site in SSC was chosen_x000D_ also having a location where the solar electricity can be pumped into the grid_x000D_ system. [4]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

Protest and resistance:

_x000D_ _x000D_

Residents from the surrounding area articulate_x000D_ the project to be more dangerous to the environment and surrounding towns than_x000D_ beneficial. Hence, the residents from Northern Virginia are protesting the_x000D_ proposed construction of the solar farm. [1]

_x000D_ _x000D_

According to an article published on NPR.org_x000D_ the heart of the protest is in a gated community named Fawn Lake._x000D_ From here residents organized against the planned solar farm arguing that that_x000D_ they do not want to have such a massive project in the back of ‘their’ gated_x000D_ community. One resident from Fawn Lake stated that he is generally in_x000D_ favor of solar energy projects, but not right at the place where he lives. [3] In fact, according to the initial_x000D_ plans of sPower the northeastern corner of the solar field abut at two_x000D_ miles with Fawn Lake. [1]

_x000D_ _x000D_

An organizer of a group named Concerned_x000D_ Citizens of Spotsylvania said that the scale of the project has been wrong._x000D_ He favors starting solar power plants in SSC, but just at a small scale.  Other protesters are worried about the solar_x000D_ project lowering the prices of their plots of land. [3] Some residents in SSC say that the_x000D_ installation of green technology is actually bad for the environment, claiming_x000D_ the loss of potential of trees reducing carbon dioxide. For the preparation of_x000D_ the solar project thousands of acres have already been chopped. [3]

_x000D_ _x000D_

The news_x000D_ channel Fox News published an article mentioning a resident blaming the_x000D_ company sPower to have chopped down the forest until 62 feet away from_x000D_ his two-story home. The same article also mentions houseowners selling their_x000D_ properties due to the planned SSEC project. [9]

_x000D_ _x000D_

The developing company replied that a vast_x000D_ amount of the neighbors will not be able to see PV power plant once it has been_x000D_ constructed and the cut-off forest areas for constructed will be afforested_x000D_ again. [3] When the local fight got the_x000D_ attention of the news channel Fox News, it stated that after the state’s_x000D_ approval it was up the county’s board of supervisors to take a decision, which_x000D_ at first hand did put off the voting. [3]

_x000D_ _x000D_

Another source mentions the meeting of a the_x000D_ Spotsylvania County Board of Supervisor that spent a night in early 2018_x000D_ listening to testimonies for 9 hours. The high school auditorium during the_x000D_ testimony was packed with the two opposing groups wearing green (pro solar) and_x000D_ red (anti solar) shirts. [4] Prior to the testimony the_x000D_ community concerns were collected during a phase of eight months. [4]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

One community concern was about sediment and_x000D_ erosion control, since another 200-acre solar farm in Essex County, Virginia_x000D_ got hit by a mudslide and eventually suffocated the nearby creeks and wetlands_x000D_ and was flowing down into the national wildlife refuge Rappahannock River. Another_x000D_ community concern expressed was the SSEC project making use of the municipal_x000D_ water line. [1]  While one concern clearly expressed was the_x000D_ one of Cadmium – a chemical component in the solar PV panels – to be a risk for_x000D_ public health, others were worries about the array being noisy, creating an_x000D_ island heat, causing brush fires or/and using up the local ground water._x000D_ Moreover, the concerns of dropping plot value and restricted view for local_x000D_ residents were expressed. [10]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

Consequence of protests:

_x000D_ _x000D_

Two out of three ‘special-use permits_x000D_ applications’ (SUPA) of the solar project have been recommended for denial. In_x000D_ consequence, the bid by the project developer sPower was in serious_x000D_ doubt. These two SUPAs account for 94% of the project’s planned area –_x000D_ respectively 470 MW of rated capacity. [6]

_x000D_ _x000D_

The deadline for the vote by the Spotsylvania_x000D_ County Board of Supervisor on the SUPA to allow sPower to proceed with_x000D_ constructions on SSEC or not was January 2nd, 2019. During the eight_x000D_ prior months the plans for the three sites have been gone through an iterative_x000D_ process

_x000D_ _x000D_

County officials included a strict set of_x000D_ conditions to gain final approval. For instance, the utilization of cadmium_x000D_ telluride (CaTe) was prohibited in the project. Further, it was restricted for_x000D_ the project to just use public water. Moreover, a bond is allotted to ensure_x000D_ the site’s clean-up once the project is retiring as well as to keep distance in_x000D_ form of a ‘350-foot setback from adjacent properties’. The recommended denial had_x000D_ over 500 votes against the project and was comprised mostly of people opposing_x000D_ the project. The final consensus finally synthesized in the size of the project_x000D_ being too big or ambitious. This is underlined by the fact that officials voted_x000D_ for the recommendation of other project approvals with the scope of a_x000D_ rated capacity of 30 MW, which was not heavily criticized but even supported by_x000D_ the local residents. [6]

_x000D_ _x000D_

Also the developer sPower acknowledged_x000D_ to maintain a safety buffer zone of at least 350 feet and cover the array with_x000D_ bushes and trees. [10]

_x000D_ _x000D_

Additionally, the water supply was switched to_x000D_ tapping into groundwater instead of using municipal water. Later, the company_x000D_ ensured that it will install tank water on its properties investing 3-5 US$_x000D_ million.  [1] (Note that however according to an_x000D_ article found on Wtop, the company agreed to utilize municipal water and_x000D_ tweaked landscaping buffers. [11])

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

Status-Quo:

_x000D_ _x000D_

In December, 2018, sPower released the_x000D_ results of a poll conducted with 400 SSC’s voters. According to company’s_x000D_ release 67% of the population support the project and 77% do have favorable_x000D_ impression of solar energy usage. After this poll’s result it was considered_x000D_ likely Planning Commission would vote in favor of a recommendation of the_x000D_ project. [8]

_x000D_ _x000D_

After debating two years of debate the SSC_x000D_ Board of Supervisors voted for approval of the special-use permit of the U.S._x000D_ East Coast’s largest power plant, thus deciding that the company sPower_x000D_ will build the project with 500 MW and costs of US million $615. [11]

_x000D_ _x000D_

On April 15, 2019 the company sPower_x000D_ released a document on SECC project’s webpage stating that it approved the_x000D_ special-use permit. Consequently, the project will be built in different phases_x000D_ during the next two years. [12]

_x000D_ _x000D_

Ahead of a community planning meeting the_x000D_ SECC’s company sPower articulated that they could do a US$ 25 million_x000D_ investment including the construction of a local park and a new fire station._x000D_ Furthermore, sPower can imagine to donate solar arrays with the value of_x000D_ US$ 1 million to the community. [1]

_x000D_ _x000D_

 

_x000D_ _x000D_

Alternative Proposals:

_x000D_ _x000D_

No alternative proposals could be found.

Airport_x000D_

On January 8th_x000D_ 2019, the portuguese government signed an agreement with VINCI (now_x000D_ full shareholder of ANA – Autoridade Nacional to significantly_x000D_ increase air traffic capacity in the two main Portuguese cities of_x000D_ Lisbon and Porto. The deal includes:

_x000D_

An expansion of the_x000D_ Portela Airport infrastructure in Lisbon which would increase_x000D_ possible air traffic by about 50%

_x000D_

An expansion of the_x000D_ Francisco Sá Carneiro Airport (Porto) which would lead to similar_x000D_ increase by about 60%

_x000D_

The building of an_x000D_ entirely new commercial airport in Montijo (southern bank of the_x000D_ Tejo) on top of the currently existing Air Force Base nº 6. This_x000D_ would also include the creation of new highway accesses to the_x000D_ airport and Vasco da Gama bridge (also owned by Vinci).

_x000D_

Not only would this_x000D_ lead to an enormous increase in air-traffic related CO2 emissions -_x000D_ the likes of which would make air-traffic the single largest cause of_x000D_ atmospheric polution in the country – but the selected area is also_x000D_ one of the largest remaining wetland ecosystems in Europe, and a_x000D_ natural wildlife reserve crucial for dozens of bird species to feed_x000D_ in. The impact on local bird populations would be disastrous, to say_x000D_ nothing of the risk it constitutes for passenger safety to have birds_x000D_ flying at low altitudes near jet turbines.
As if this decision in_x000D_ itself wasn't bad enough, the conditions under which this deal was_x000D_ signed are in blantant disregard for EU laws pertaining to the need to_x000D_ perform an environmentl impact study prior to the construction of_x000D_ these projects. The preliminary study was completed in late July, and_x000D_ as we expected, it's findings are confusing to say the least: It_x000D_ warns of grave environmental and safety risks, but says the location_x000D_ is viable. The project is now in a period of public consultation_x000D_ until the 19th of September, though participation by the_x000D_ population has been predictably low; We also believe the choice of_x000D_ this period is not an accident either, as August and September are_x000D_ the months in which most of the population is on holidays and is less_x000D_ likely to notice or protest this governmental decision, which is_x000D_ plainly detrimental to public and ecological health and serves the_x000D_ capitalistic interests of those who would truly profit with this_x000D_ deal:the multinational corporation VINCI and certain members within the_x000D_ Portuguese political class.
